channel.title: Arbitrary Data Analysis
channel.description: Recent content on Arbitrary Data Analysis

item.title: test post citizenship acquisition of Brits in the EU
item.description: This is just a test post Hi everyone. This is just a test post. I am trying to sort out how I could create a blog with R (using the blogdown package) on github pages. This description - among other great online resources - helped me doing it. To test if it works, I show below citizenship acquisitions of British people in other EU country before and after Brexit vote.

item.title: test post
item.description: This is just a test post This is a plot of citizenship acquisitions of British people in other EU country before and after Brexit vote. First the R code (based on the wonderful packages: tidyverse and eurostat) dat %>% filter(citizen == "UK") %>% filter(sex == "T" & age == "TOTAL" & agedef == "REACH" & geo %in% EUlist) %>% filter(geo != "UK") %>% filter(time > "2007-01-01") %>% mutate(year = str_sub(time, 1, 4)) %>% group_by(time, year) %>% summarise(values = sum(values)) %>% ggplot() + geom_col(aes(year, values)) + geom_text(aes(year, values, label = values), vjust = -0.

item.title: test post 2
item.description: second test here is some text library(tidyverse) ## -- Attaching packages ---------------------------------------- tidyverse 1.2.1 -- ## v ggplot2 3.1.0 v purrr 0.2.5 ## v tibble 2.0.1 v dplyr 0.7.8 ## v tidyr 0.8.2 v stringr 1.3.1 ## v readr 1.3.1 v forcats 0.3.0 ## -- Conflicts ------------------------------------------- tidyverse_conflicts() -- ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() a <- rnorm(100, 10, 1) b <- rnorm(100, 11, 0.5) plot(a, b) here we go

item.title: About
item.description: This is a “hello world” example website for the blogdown package. The theme was forked from @jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme and modified by Yihui Xie.
